coredata.dc:title: Vibrational energy relaxation in dense fluid H2: Comparison of experiments and binary-collision models
coredata.dc:creator: Tardieu, A.
Chātelet, M.
Oksengorn, B.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
A detailed analysis is given for the vibrational energy relaxation rate in dense fluid H2 using the framework of Chesnoy's binary-collision model. It is shown that this model reproduces qualitatively the experimental behaviour: however, the temperature dependence given by this model is slightly different from that obtained using low-density binary-collision dynamics.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 120, number 4,5 CHEMICAL PHYSCIS LETTERS 18 October 1985 VIBRATIONAL ENERGY RELAXATION IN DENSE FLUID H2' COMPARISON OF EXPERIMENTS AND BINARY-COLLISION MODELS A- TARDIEU M CHATELET and B OKSENGORN lyboraroire des Inrerarrions Alolrrulaires er des Hautes Pressions CNRS Uniccrsire Paris -Nord 934-iO Villetaneuse France Recened 14 June 1985 in final form 30 July 1985 A detailed analysis is green for the %tbrat,onal energy relaxation rate to dense fluid H_ using the framework of Chesnoy s binary-collision model It is shown that this model reproduces quahiatt%tly the experimental behavior howe%er the temperature dependence gt,en by this model is slightly different from that obtained using low-density binary-collision dyr_imtcs 1 Introduction In the last decade many experimental studies have been carried out to determine the V-R,T transfer rate for vibrational energy of diatomic molecules in dense media (liquid, solid or highly compressed gas phases), particularly in the case of pure hydrogen [1,21 For this molecular system experimental values of the vibrational relaxation time Tl have been obtained for a large range of densities (up to 3 5 X 10'-'- molecules cm-3) and temperatures (14-400 K) At low density the vibrational relaxation rate follows a linear density dependence, reflecting a binarycollision relaxation process This relaxation rate is given theoretically using the isolated binary-collision (IBC) approximation by the following expression Ti' =Ppc, (1) where P is the transfer probability for one binary collision, and vc the collision frequency which is linearly density dependent In the low-density range However, when the density increases to large values, strong non-lineanties appear in the density dependence of the relaxation rate. In a recent review, a discussion is given of the most important measurements in dense phases and of different theoretical approaches and models for vibrational energy relaxation in dense media as a function of density and temperature [3] For the high-density range, the first model was given by 356 Lttovitz and Madigosky [4] by assuming the IBC approximation for the relaxation process, only the collision frequency vc is density dependent, and is deduced from the mean free path calculated in the framework of a moving-wall cell model. This model is very crude and cannot describe accurately the density dependence over a large range [2,5]_ A more elaborate model has been put forward by Delalande and Gale [6], who also use the IBC approximation, and introduce a hard-core repulsive potential perturbed by an attractive tall for calculating the frequency of the collisions responsible for the relaxation process In this model the relaxation rate is related to the density and temperature pair distribution function evaluated at the hard-core diameter Q7gHS(P,T,°) calculated using the Carnahan and Starling expression (7], and is given by Tll(P.T)=k(T)p81.1g(p,T,a)exp(-Qe). (23 where k(T) is the relaxation constant in the low-density gas, p the number density, p = 1/kHT with kp die Holtzmann constant, and a the well depth of the at tractive tall A careful comparison between thus model and the experimental results for highly compressed HZ has shown that there is only qualitative agreement. the hard-core diameters a deduced from the fits with the relation (2) and the high-density values of the relaxation rate are 7% larger than the theoretical hard-core diameters (2,5J_ 0 009-2614/85/$ 03.30 © Elsevier Science Publishers B V. [ 1 ] e) Experimental results from ref. [2] In an effort to get a better understanding of the relaxation process to dense phases, Chesnoy has refined the Delalande and Gale model, using a more realistic potential given by a spherical potential u(r) with a "soft core" and an attractive tail [8]. He calculated the relaxation rate in the dense phases from the general expression given by Davis and Oppenheim [9] on the basis of a statistical-mechanical approach- 'A] 245 0 L75 175 225 275 325 10 T H, Fig 1. Comparison between the experimental values of the specific distance Rexp and the calculated values Rcaj, as a function of temperature. o,+ values of Rexp obtained by fitting the experimental results for Hz given by Chatelet [ 2 J with the Chesnoy model [8]. x values of R*,p obtained by flitting the experimental results for HZ given Ty 1)ela7ande (1] with the Chesnoy model [8]. o- values of Rcal calculated for a colLnear collision of two partners o- values of Rcaj calculated for a binary collision by taking into account the computed probability of V-T transfer for H2 [ 13 ]. PgasT~IpbqTl q =gliq(R*)/ggas(R*), the relaxation process occurring around a specific distance R" close to the molecular diameter, but slightly smaller than the latter; the pair distribution functions taken at this specific distance R* are calculated to determLtie the binary-collision frequencies in low- and high-density phases. Chesnoy has obtained the relation T, 1(P,T1=k(T)PYHS(R*)exp(-ssE), where the function yHS(R *) in the dense phase is related to the pair distribution function taken at the specific distance R* by the expression gc(R *) = exP (-P[v(R *) + e] }YHg(R *) uL the theoretical framework developed by Andersen et al (AWC) [10]- In ties paper we give a detailed analysis of the experimental results for H2 obtained to the high-density range for several isotherms, using the Chesnoy model. 2. Calculations and discussion It is easy to show that the function yHS(R*) is not far from the hard-sphere pair distribution function gHS(a)• when the ratio (a -R *)/a is small [81, the hard-sphere diameter a being evaluated by the AWC theory [10]. In tlus oseyHS(R`) is related analytical- 357 Volume 120, number 4,5 CHEMJCAL PHYSICS LETTERS 18 October 1985 ly to gHS(a) by a formula given by Chesnoy [8] We have determined the values of the specific distance Rexp in the high-density range by fitting relation (3) with the experimental values of the relaxation time for several isotherms in ale flwd phase. At 35 and 50 K the results obtained by Olalande [I ] have been used, the other isotherms have been taken from measurements by Chatelet [2] For the isotherms at 35, 50 and 77 K a quantum correction has been added to the well depth e, by using a classical equivalent eCE obtained by following the Delalande and Gale method [1 ] (a Lennard-Jones potential has been used eu = 37 K, aE, = 2 96 A) A that the values of R,*.1 are close to those of the classical turning point corresponding to the velocity V*, this approximation seems adequate, since it is known that many strong-interaction processes occur m the vicinity of the timing point For the calculation of V*, the values of L for Hz have been obtained ruing the Herzfeld method [12]_ In this collinear model, the probability of transfer is independent of the rotation of the diatomic molecule, however, In the case of H.,, many calculations and ex periments have shown that the rotational levels must be taken into account [13,14] Consequently, we have calculated another series ofR~ using the method pro posed by Yardley [15] _ The values of V* were deduced from the crossing between the curve of the distribution function for the relative energy of the collision and the curve of the transfer cross section as a function of en ergy, as computed by Lukasik [13] Table ] shows the values of the hard-sphere diameter aAwc the different specific distances R*, and the ratios R~/a,ev„C_ It can be seen that the values of R Xp* all between the two series of calculated values of RO, and that the ratios Rexp/QAWC remain in the narrow range 0_95-0 85. On the other hand, fig 1 shows a comparison, as a function of temperature, between the experimental valuesR*~t~p and the two series of calculated values RO the latter iollow a Landau-Teller-type law with almost 358 the same slope, while the temperature dependence of the former is slightly different Nevertheless, one could expect a very similar behavior as a function of temperature, since the same gas-like approximation is made at high and low density. 3. Concluding remarks Our analysis of the experimental results for H2, In terms of the most refined btnary-collision model given by Chesnoy [8], shows that this kind of model O qualitatively reproduce the experimental results for HZ In other respects, it seems difficult to observe possible effects of ternary correlations, as shown by Chesnoy and Gale [3], more accurate results for different systems of pure fluids or mixtures must be obtained as a function of density, temperature and concentration to test these effects Finally, computer simulations in dense phases could complement the study of these different contributions, as suggested by several authors [3,16] References [ 1 ] C Delalande, These d'Eiat, Universite Pans XI (1979) [2] ht Chatelet. head.ce:title: Vibrational energy relaxation in dense fluid H2: Comparison of experiments and binary-collision models

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Laboratoire des Interactions Molèculaires et des Hautes Pressions, CNRS, Université Paris-Nord, 93430 Villetaneuse, France

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: A detailed analysis is given for the vibrational energy relaxation rate in dense fluid H2 using the framework of Chesnoy's binary-collision model. It is shown that this model reproduces qualitatively the experimental behaviour: however, the temperature dependence given by this model is slightly different from that obtained using low-density binary-collision dynamics.
